question: I am comfortable making decisions that deviate from guidelines when clinically justified.
I feel uncomfortable making decisions without comprehensive information.
I perform better when the clinical environment is predictable and structured.
When uncertain, I prefer to intervene early rather than risk deterioration.
I enjoy the challenge of managing chaotic or rapidly changing shifts.
I rely heavily on protocols and guidelines when making clinical decisions.
Colleagues often look to me for clarity or direction in uncertain moments.
I feel uneasy when rushed into making rapid clinical decisions.
I naturally help bridge communication gaps between different team members.
I am quick to incorporate new evidence or techniques into my clinical practice.
I quickly form an initial impression of a case before gathering full details.
I investigate aggressively when I suspect a serious underlying condition.
Even under pressure, I take time to think before intervening.
I actively reflect on my clinical decisions to improve my future performance.
I trust my clinical intuition even when evidence is incomplete.
High-pressure environments drain me more than they energise me.
I tend to avoid interventions unless they are urgently necessary.
I actively seek out new tools, technologies, or ideas that improve patient care.
I tend to work quietly and independently without sharing much along the way.
I can shift my pace easily depending on how the clinical situation evolves.
I prefer to stabilise a situation before making broader clinical decisions.
I prefer to stick to established methods rather than experiment with new approaches.
I easily recognise patterns or diagnoses based on subtle clues.
I prefer minimal discussion when I have already decided on a plan.
I enjoy learning from unusual or complex cases that challenge standard thinking.
I communicate clearly and directly during high-pressure situations.
In critical events, I often take the lead without waiting for direction.
I adapt well when priorities shift unexpectedly during a shift.
I prefer to follow a structured diagnostic pathway, even when time is limited.
I remain calm and effective when multiple issues demand attention at once.
I prefer conservative treatment approaches unless strong evidence suggests otherwise.
I often explore multiple differential diagnoses before committing to a plan.
I prioritise maintaining harmony within the team, even during conflict.
I feel uneasy taking clinical risks, even small ones.
I adapt my style easily when working in different clinical environments.
I can stabilise myself quickly after stressful clinical events.
I work best when things move fast and require immediate action.
I adjust my communication style depending on who I am working with.
I find it difficult to think clearly when multiple emergencies arise simultaneously.
I am cautious about adopting new practices until they are widely accepted.
I act quickly and confidently in situations where delays could worsen patient outcomes.
I escalate care early rather than waiting to see how the case progresses.
